choices.text: X-Linked Recessive Ichthyosis - Steroid Sulfatase Deficiency
Autosomal Recessive Congenital Ichthyosis - Lamellar Ichthyosis
Harlequin Icthyosis - Mutations of the ABCA12 Genes

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT match related to types of icthyosis & their characteristic features among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Collodion membrane- Icthyosis Vulgaris

 

Option D.

 

  • Ichthyosis Vulgaris does not present with Collodion Membrane at Birth and is therefore a Wrong Match
  • Salient features of important Ichthyoses.

 

 

 

Collodion membrane:

 

  • Neonate encased in a shiny, Parchment-like Membrane (Collodion Baby), suggestive of disorder belonging to the Autosomal Recessive Congenital Ichthyosis (ARCI) spectrum.
  • Below image depicts, ARCI, in which shedding of collodion membranes is seen after 1 week.

 

 

  • The membrane usually peels off within the first 4 weeks of life.
  • Initially, the clinical presentation can be quite severe and often includes ectropion and everted lips of different degrees. This later clear.

 

Option B: Lamellar icthyosis

 

  • Eclabium & Ectropion in Lamellar icthyosis are seen in the below image:

 

 

All Collodion babies look alike at birth, but later take different clinical course, such as:

 

  • Lamellar Ichthyosis: after the collodion membrane sheds, the trunk and scalp develop large, dark gray to brownish scales, sparing the face and extremities.
  • Bathing Suit Ichthyosis: a lamellar form of the disease that spares the face and extremities and is distributed in a bathing suit pattern.
  • Self-Healing Collodion Baby.
  • Congenital Icthyosiform Erythroderma.
  • Acral Self-Healing Collodion Baby

 

Option C: Harlequin Icthyosis:

 

Harlequin Icthyosis

 

  • The most severe form of autosomal recessive congenital icthyosis is called harlequin icthyosis.
  • The ABCA12 genes mutations are seen. (option C)
  • Nearly the entire body has thickened skin at birth. Neonatal skin resembles armor at birth. Deep cracks separate the large, armor like plates that make up the skin.

 

Below image depicts a neonate with Harlequin icthyosis presenting with Armor like plates,

 

Eclabium & Ectropion.

 

 

  • Early in life, supportive care is usually needed continuously. Treatment options include retinoids, antibiotics, etretinate, and moisturizing cream.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A collodion membrane at birth is associated with lamellar ichthyosis, part of the group of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyoses, and not with ichthyosis vulgaris.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Page no. 65.4 to 65.10

questions.text: CT brain shows tram-track cortical calcifications as shown in the below image in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sturge Weber Syndrome

 

Option B.

 

  • The CT brain showing tram-track cortical calcifications can be seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Seizures & port-wine stain ('devil's stain'), are suggestive of Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS), which is a severe neurocutaneous disorder.
    • The Ophthalmic (V1) and Maxillary (V2) Divisions of the Trigeminal Nerve are primarily affected by the port-wine stain, which is a vascular plaque (capillary malformation) over the lateral aspect of the forehead.
    • In addition to Contralateral Seizures or Hemiparesis, it also Exhibits Ipsilateral Leptomeningeal Angiomas.

 

 

  • Port-Wine Stain: It does not resolve spontaneously and is usually treated by a Pulsed Dye Laser.
  • Investigations:
    • Tram-track cortical calcifications, a sign of Sturge-Weber syndrome, can be seen on a CT scan of the brain.
    • It happens as a result of a vascular steal that affects the nearby cortex and white matter, causing localized ischemia and calcification.
    • This is caused by a leptomeningeal haemangioma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome:

 

  • It is characterized by hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system and retina, renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and other tumors, not by tram-track calcifications on brain imaging.

 

Option C. Tuberous sclerosis:

 

  • It is typically associated with cortical tubers, sub-ependymal nodules, and sub-ependymal giant cell astrocytomas, not the tram-track calcifications seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Option D. Ataxia-telangiectasia:

 

  • It is a condition associated with Cerebellar Ataxia, Oculocutaneous Telangiectasias, Immunodeficiency, and increased risk for Malignancies, but not with the type of calcifications seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tram-Track Cortical Calcifications on a CT brain scan are indicative of Sturge-Weber Syndrome.

 

Ref: Journal: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4225308/

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 73, Page No 73.2

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume III Chapter 116 Page Nos 116.1-116.10

questions.text: A young girl having low intelligence presented as shown below. There is history of epilepsy. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberous Sclerosis

 

Option B.

 

  • The image shows Angiofibroma’s, and in the background of low intelligence and Epilepsy history.
  • It points to the diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis (TS) / Epiloia (Epilepsy Low intelligence & Angiofibroma / Adenoma sebaceum).
  • Other cutaneous features of tuberous sclerosis:
    • Angiofibroma / Adenoma sebaceum: Firm, distinct, reddish-brown, telangiectatic papules with a diameter of 1 to 10 mm that enlarge during puberty but then remain unchanged.
    • They sometimes appear in the ears and extend from the nasolabial furrows to the cheeks and chin.

 

 

  • Shagreen Patch: A soft, skin-coloured plaque that is irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, and typically found in the lumbosacral region.

 

 

  • Ash-leaf macules:
    • They are typically found on the trunk or limbs and are white, ovoid or ash-leaf shaped, measuring 1-3 cm in length.
    • They are most easily seen when examined under Wood's light.
    • They are an important physical indicator because they can appear at birth or in the first few months of life, several years before other symptoms of the disease manifest.

 

 

  • Periungual fibroma / Koenen’s tumour: They appear at or after puberty as smooth, firm, flesh-colored excrescences emerging from the nail folds.

 

 

  • Firm fibromatous plaques, particularly on the forehead and scalp, soft pedunculated fibromas around the neck and axillae, and polio are some other cutaneous manifestations.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis:

 

  • Neurofibromatosis typically presents with café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, and Lisch nodules, not the facial angiofibromas seen in the image, which are commonly associated with tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • SLE is an autoimmune condition characterized by a broad spectrum of clinical presentations including malar rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, and systemic involvement, but not the specific facial lesions shown in the image.

 

Option D. Systemic Sclerosis:

 

  • Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is associated with skin thickening, fibrosis, and in some cases, telangiectasia, but not with the facial angiofibromas and neurological symptoms seen in tuberous sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical triad of Facial Angiofibromas, Epilepsy, and Cognitive Impairment is indicative of Tuberous Sclerosis.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 80, Page Nos 80.10-80.11

choices.text: Lisch's Nodules are an important Ocular Manifestation
Ash Leaf Macules can be seen

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement regarding Neurofibromatosis-I (NF-I) among the given options?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ash Leaf Macules can be seen

 

Option B. Ash-leaf macules:

 

  • They are typically found on the trunk or limbs and are white, ovoid or ash-leaf shaped, measuring 1-3 cm in length.
  • They are most easily seen when examined under Wood's light.
  • They are an important physical indicator because they can appear at birth or in the first few months of life, several years before other symptoms of the disease manifest.

 

 

Explanation:

 

  • Neurofibromatosis-I (NF-I) / Von Recklinghausen's disease: Autosomal dominant disorder.
  • For diagnosis of NF-I, two or more of the following should be present:
    • 6 or more café-au-lait Spots
    • 2 or more Neurofibromas or one Plexiform Neuroma
    • Freckling in the axillary or inguinal region
    • 2 or more Lisch nodules
    • Dysplasia of the sphenoidal or tibial bones
    • First degree relative with NF1
    • Optic Gliomas
  • Neurofibromas:

 

 

Option A: Lisch Nodules

 

  • Lisch Nodules:
    • These are Hamartomas which are melanocytic, and they are typically brown or yellow in color.
    • They are typically visible with the unaided eye and appear as rounded elevations on the iris surface.
    • Slit-lamp examination, however, provides the most accurate evaluation.
    • They do not produce visual impairment.
  • The image below shows Lisch's nodules, the most common ocular manifestation of neurofibromatosis type 1.

 

 

  • Optic Glioma in NF-1

 

 

Option C: Axillary Freckling

 

  • The image below shows neurofibromatosis: Axillary Freckling (Crowes sign) and Café-au-lait spots.

 

 

Option D: Buttonhole Sign

 

  • Buttonhole Sign is seen in type 1 neurofibromatosis.
  • Buttonhole Sign: Lesion gets invaginated by finger pressure (On applying pressure the lesion goes back in the skin and comes out on removing the pressure.

 

 

  • This sign is also positive in anetoderma and dermatofibroma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While Lisch Nodules, Axillary Freckling, and the Button-Hole Sign are associated with Neurofibromatosis-I, Ash Leaf Macules are not a feature of NF-I and instead are indicative of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume III Chapter 80 Page Nos 80.1-80.5

Journal: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3505421/

choices.text: Defect in Filaggrin Protein occurs

questions.text: Identify the FALSE statement regarding Ichthyosis vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal Recessive Disorder

 

Option A.

 

  • Ichthyosis vulgaris (I.V) / 'Fish scale disease' is an autosomal dominant disorder (NOT Autosomal Recessive), which presents clinically with fish-like (Icthyos-fish) scales & dry skin.
  • Fish like scales in I.V

 

 

  • Hyperlinear palms & keratosis pilaris can be seen associated with I.V.

 

 

  • Pathogenesis in I.V: Reduced or absence of filaggrin protein and granular layer is noted. It happens when the skin fails to exfoliate its dead skin cells. As a result, small patches of dry, dead skin cells form on the surface, particularly on the arms and legs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ichthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with a defect in filaggrin protein, presenting with hyperlinear palms and fish-like scales.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 65 Page No 65.2, 65.4, 65.5

choices.text: Freckling should be checked in the Groin
It is due to a Mutation in Neurofibromin on Chromosome 18
Lisch Nodules can cause Vision Loss in this patient
3 or more Café-au-lait Macules should be present to confirm the Diagnosis

questions.text: A patient presented with Multiple Soft Nodules and Hyperpigmented Macules as shown in the picture. Which of the following statement is CORRECT regarding the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Freckling should be checked in the Groin

 

Option A.

 

  • Clinical diagnosis from the description and the image shown is Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1) or Von Recklinghausen disease.
  • In addition to axillary freckling, inguinal freckling is another important diagnostic criterion for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).

 

 

  • The presence of freckling in these areas supports the diagnosis of NF1, along with other features such as café-au-lait macules.

 

For diagnosis of NF-1, two or more of the following should be present:

 

  • 6 or more café-au-lait spots
  • 2 or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neuroma
  • Freckling in the axillary or inguinal region
  • 2 or more Lisch nodules
  • Dysplasia of the sphenoidal or tibial bones
  • First degree relative with NF1
  • Optic gliomas

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. It is due to a mutation in neurofibromin on chromosome 18:

 

  • The mutation associated with NF1 is in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17, not chromosome 18.
  • This gene is responsible for producing neurofibromin, a protein that suppresses tumour growth.

 

Option C. Lisch nodules can cause vision loss in this patient:

 

  • Lisch nodules, which are iris hamartomas found in NF1, are generally asymptomatic and do not typically result in vision loss.

 

 

  • They are, however, useful in the diagnosis of NF1.

 

Option D. 3 or more café-au-lait macules should be present to confirm the diagnosis:

 

  • The diagnostic criteria for NF1 require six or more café-au-lait macules of a specific size, depending on the age of the patient (over 5 mm in diameter pre-puberty and over 15 mm in diameter post-puberty).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The diagnosis of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) can be supported by the presence of inguinal or axillary freckling, in addition to other criteria such as six or more café-au-lait macules.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 80.3

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 985

choices.text: It has Autosomal Dominant Inheritance
Axillary Freckling is Absent
Hamartomas in Kidney are seen
Affected Gene is present on Chromosome 22

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding Neuro-Fibromatosis Type 2 EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hamartomas in Kidney are seen

 

Option C:

 

  • Renal hamartomas are a classical feature of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC), not NF2. NF2 is more commonly associated with Central Nervous System Tumors like Schwannomas and Meningiomas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It has Autosomal dominant inheritance:

 

  • Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the development of bilateral vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, ependymomas, and other nervous system tumors.

 

Option B. Axillary Freckling is absent:

 

  • Axillary freckling is a feature of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), not NF2. NF2 has different clinical manifestations, primarily related to the central nervous system.

 

Option D. Affected gene is present on Chromosome 22:

 

  • The gene associated with NF2 is located on chromosome 22 and is responsible for producing a protein called Merlin (or Schwannomin) that suppresses Tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Renal Hamartomas are not associated with Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) but are a feature of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC).
  • NF2 is characterized by Bilateral Vestibular Schwannomas and other CNS Tumors, with the Affected Gene located on Chromosome 22.

 

Ref:  Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 993

choices.text: X Linked Recessive Icthyosis

questions.text: Which of the following icthyosis presents with a Collodion membrane?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lamellar Ichthyosis

 

Option D.

 

  • Lamellar Ichthyosis typically presents with a collodion membrane at birth—a tight, shiny, almost transparent film that covers the skin and is then shed to reveal the characteristic large, dark, plate-like scales of the disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ichthyosis Vulgaris:

 

  • Ichthyosis Vulgaris typically presents with fine scaling, particularly on the extensor surfaces of the limbs, without a collodion membrane at birth.
  • It is the most common form of ichthyosis and is often associated with atopy.

 

Option B. X-Linked Recessive Ichthyosis:

 

  • This condition presents with large, dark scales and is seen in males due to its X-linked inheritance.
  • It does not typically present with a collodion membrane at birth.

 

Option C. Bullous Ichthyosiform Erythroderma:

 

  • This condition, also known as epidermolytic hyperkeratosis, does present at birth, it is characterized by widespread erythema, blistering, and erosions rather than a collodion membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lamellar Ichthyosis as the ichthyosis subtype that presents with a collodion membrane at birth, which is a tight, shiny casing that is eventually shed to reveal scaly skin beneath.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 65.7

questions.text: A child was born with membranes around the body and had ectropion and eclabium. He is brought to the OPD with lesions covering his face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ichthyosis Vulgaris

 

Option A: Ichthyosis vulgaris

 

  • The clinical image depicts a new born covered in a shiny membrane that resembles parchment, suggesting a disorder on the autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum (Lamellar ichthyosis, Bathing suit ichthyosis, Harlequin ichthyosis)
  • Icthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutation in the Filaggrin Gene (FLG).
  • Ichthyosis Vulgaris is unlikely because it does not manifest at birth.

 

 

Fig: Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis, Shedding of collodion membranes after 1 week.

 

  • Description: This is the most common type of ichthyosis and is characterized by dry, scaly skin. It typically doesn't manifest at birth but becomes evident in early childhood.
  • Reason for exclusion as the diagnosis: The presentation in ichthyosis vulgaris is milder than the description provided and does not present with the characteristic membrane, ectropion, and eclabium at birth.
  • Thus, this might be the "unlikely" diagnosis based on the scenario given.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lamellar Ichthyosis

 

  • Description: Infants with lamellar ichthyosis are often born with a collodion membrane, which sheds after a few weeks.
  • The skin then becomes darkly pigmented with large, plate-like scales. Ectropion and eclabium can also be present.

 

Option C. Bathing Suit Ichthyosis

 

  • Description: This is a rare type of ichthyosis where the scaling is restricted to the trunk, sparing the extremities and face.
  • It's called "Bathing Suit" due to the distribution pattern resembling the Area covered by a Bathing Suit.

 

Option D. Harlequin Ichthyosis

 

  • Description: This is a severe form of ichthyosis, where infants are born with very thick skin that forms large, diamond-shaped plates separated by deep fissures as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Features like ectropion, eclabium, and respiratory difficulties are common.

 

Autosomal Recessive Congenital Ichthyosis (ARCI) includes the following:

 

  • Lamellar Ichthyosis (LI)
  • Bathing Suit Ichthyosis (BSI)
  • Harlequin Ichthyosis (HI)
  • Congenital Ichthyosiform Erythroderma (CIE)
  • Self-Limiting Congenital Ichthyisis (SLCI)
  • Collodion Baby

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ichthyosis vulgaris is an unlikely diagnosis in a new-born presenting with a Collodion Membrane, Ectropion, Eclabium, and Extensive Skin Lesions, given that Ichthyosis Vulgaris is typically a Milder Form and less likely to present with such severe symptoms at Birth.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 65 Page No 65.4, 65.6-65.10

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8161842/

questions.text: An infant presented with generalized dry skin and fish-like scales, which appeared 3 months after birth. The child's mother also reports that the infant seems to be uncomfortable in hot environments. On physical examination, the palms display accentuated skin markings as shown below. What additional finding is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keratosis Pilaris

 

Option B.

 

  • Ichthyosis Vulgaris is the diagnosis from the description given in the Clinical vignette and it is often associated with Keratosis Pilaris, which presents as Small, Rough Bumps typically found on the Upper Arms and Thighs.

 

 

  • These bumps are due to the build up of keratin in the hair follicles.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Erythroderma:

 

  • Erythroderma, which is a generalized redness of the skin, is not typically a finding associated with Ichthyosis Vulgaris.
  • It can be seen in other more severe forms of ichthyosis or different dermatological conditions.

 

Option C. Lid Eversion:

 

  • Lid eversion, or ectropion, is not a typical finding in Ichthyosis Vulgaris.

 

 

  • Ectropion is more commonly associated with other types of ichthyosis, such as Harlequin ichthyosis.

 

Option D. Undescended Testes:

 

  • Undescended testes are associated with X Linked Recessive Ichthyosis.
  • Undescended testes are not associated with Ichthyosis Vulgaris.
  • This finding is not related to the condition and would prompt an evaluation for other issues, such as congenital or endocrinological abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ichthyosis Vulgaris is commonly associated with Keratosis Pilaris, which presents as Small, Rough Bumps on the Upper Arms and Thighs, along with the characteristic Dry Skin with Fish-Like Scales and increased Skin Markings on the palms.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 65.4

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with a history of hyperlipidaemia presents to the dermatology clinic with a 6-month history of progressively worsening dry skin and scaling. He describes the scales as resembling fish skin and reports they are most prominent on his lower legs. His medications include atorvastatin, which was started approximately 7 months ago. He denies any history of similar skin conditions in himself or his family. Physical examination reveals diffuse, fine, white scaling on the lower extremities without erythema. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Drug-Induced Acquired Ichthyosis

 

Option B.

 

  • Acquired ichthyosis can be induced by certain medications, including statins like atorvastatin. The temporal relationship between the initiation of atorvastatin and the onset of symptoms, along with the absence of personal or family history of similar skin conditions, supports this diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option A. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis typically presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales and is commonly found on extensor surfaces, the scalp, and the sacral area, which is not described in this patient's presentation.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism:

 

  • Hypothyroidism can cause dry, coarse skin and may mimic ichthyosis, but there is no indication of other symptoms of hypothyroidism in the patient's history or presentation.

 

Option D. X-Linked Ichthyosis:

 

  • X-Linked Ichthyosis is a genetic condition that typically presents in early life, not acutely in adulthood. Moreover, it is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern, affecting primarily males, with the mother being the carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drug-induced acquired ichthyosis is a potential side effect of statin therapy, particularly when the skin changes develop after the initiation of the medication and there is no prior personal or family history of similar skin conditions.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 87.1

choices.text: Tram Track Calcifications seen on MRI Brain
Glaucoma is an Eye Finding
Bilateral Port Wine Stain seen over Face

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to a seizure. He has a history of a red-purplish discoloration on his face since birth. His mother reports that he has been experiencing episodes of eye redness and tearing, which an ophthalmologist diagnosed as increased intraocular pressure. A brain MRI is ordered, which shows gyriform calcifications. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral Port Wine Stain Seen over Face

 

Option D.

 

  • The diagnosis of the given clinical vignette is Sturge Weber Syndrome.
  • The port wine stain, also known as a Nevus Flammeus, is typically Unilateral and follows the distribution of the Trigeminal Nerve.

 

 

  • Bilateral presentation is not characteristic of Sturge-Weber syndrome and suggests a different or additional diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tram Track calcifications seen on MRI Brain:

 

In Sturge-Weber syndrome, MRI of the brain can show "tram track" calcifications that correspond to the areas of Leptomeningeal Angioma.

 

 

  • MRI axial T2-weighted fast-field echo sequence showing subcortical calcifications with characteristic ‘tram-track’-like appearance involving the left frontal and parietal regions.

 

Option B. Seizures seen:

 

  • Seizures are a common neurological manifestation in Sturge-Weber syndrome due to the involvement of leptomeningeal angiomas.

 

Option C. Glaucoma is an Eye finding:

 

  • Glaucoma is a common ocular finding in Sturge-Weber syndrome, often caused by increased episcleral venous pressure due to associated angiomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Sturge-Weber syndrome, the port wine stain is typically unilateral and associated with "tram track" calcifications on brain MRI, seizures, and glaucoma, distinguishing it from other neurocutaneous disorders.

 

Ref: Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 73.2

questions.text: Match the following Genodermatoses in Column A with Associated Symptoms / Signs in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d

 

Correct matches:

 

 

Explanation:

 

1. Neurofibromatosis-1 (c Crowe’s sign):

 

  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), also known as von Recklinghausen disease, can present with Crowe’s sign, which is axillary or inguinal freckling, one of the diagnostic criteria for NF1.

 

2. Sturge-Weber Syndrome (a Glaucoma):

 

  • Sturge-Weber syndrome is associated with glaucoma due to elevated episcleral venous pressure. It is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by a facial port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angiomas, and ocular abnormalities.

 

3. Bourneville’s Disease (b Ash Leaf Macules):

 

  • Bourneville’s disease, also known as Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC), is associated with ash leaf macules, which are hypopigmented lesions typically found on the trunk and extremities.

 

4. Neurofibromatosis-2 (d Bilateral Acoustic Neuromas):

 

  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is associated with Bilateral Acoustic Neuromas (Vestibular Schwannomas), which are Benign Tumors that affect the nerve responsible for hearing and balance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genodermatosis with its associated symptom/sign: Neurofibromatosis-1 with Crowe’s sign, Sturge-Weber syndrome with glaucoma, Bourneville’s Disease with ash leaf macules, and Neurofibromatosis-2 with bilateral acoustic neuromas.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 73.2, 78.2, 80.3, 80.11

choices.text: Bourneville’s Disease and 9, 22
Neurofibromatosis -1 and 17, 22
Bourneville’s Disease and 9, 16

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presented with lesions over her fingers since past 10 years as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis associated with these nail changes and which of the following chromosomes can be affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bourneville’s Disease and 9, 16

 

Option D.

 

  • The image depicts Periungual Fibromas, also known as Koenen's tumors, which are characteristic of Bourneville’s disease, better known as Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC).
  • These benign skin growths typically develop around the nails and are one of the major diagnostic features of TSC.
  • TSC is associated with mutations in the TSC1 gene on chromosome 9 and TSC2 gene on chromosome 16.
  • The nail changes in the image are consistent with TSC.
  • I Hope you do remember Tamanna to memorise the numerical here.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis -1 and 18, 22:

 

  • The cutaneous manifestations of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) include café-au-lait spots, Neurofibromas, and Axillary Freckling, not periungual fibromas, and the NF1 gene is located on chromosome 17, not 18.

 

Option B. Bourneville’s Disease and 9, 22:

 

  • TSC is associated with Bourneville’s disease; the affected genes are TSC1 on chromosome 9 and TSC2 on chromosome 16, not 22.

 

Option C. Neurofibromatosis -1 and 17, 22:

 

  • The nail changes shown are not typically seen with NF1, which is associated with chromosome 17.
  • NF2 is associated with chromosome 22 and is characterized by Bilateral Acoustic Neuromas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Periungual Fibromas is a sign of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC), which is associated with mutations in the TSC1 gene on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene on chromosome 16.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 80.10

choices.text: Measurement of Intraocular Tension

questions.text: A patient had irregular hyperpigmented patches on the trunk and multiple small hyperpigmented macules in the axillae and groins since early childhood. There were no other skin lesions. Which is the most likely investigation to support the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Slit Lamp Examination of Eye

 

Option D:

 

  • A slit lamp examination is a key investigation for identifying Lisch nodules on the iris, which are characteristic of NF1 and can help support the diagnosis when the skin findings are consistent with the disease.

 

 

  • The clinical presentation of irregular hyperpigmented patches on the trunk and multiple small hyperpigmented macules in the axillae and groins is suggestive of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).
  • One of the diagnostic features of NF1 is the presence of Lisch nodules, which are pigmented iris hamartomas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Retinal Artery Angiography:

 

  • This investigation is used to visualize the blood vessels in the retina, not the iris, and is not typically indicated for the diagnosis of NF1.

 

Option B. Examination of Fundus:

 

  • For the specific diagnosis of NF1, as the fundus examination focuses on the internal surfaces of the eye, such as the retina, and would not typically reveal Lisch nodules.

 

Option C. Measurement of Intraocular Tension:

 

  • This test is used primarily for the diagnosis and monitoring of glaucoma, which is not a direct diagnostic feature of NF1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Slit lamp examination is crucial for diagnosing Neurofibromatosis Type 1 as it allows for the visualization of Lisch nodules, which are melanocytic iris hamartomas associated with the condition.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 80.3

questions.text: All of the following are seen associated with Tuberous Sclerosis EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Axillary Freckles

 

Option D.

 

  • Axillary freckles, also known as Crowe's sign, are not typically seen in TSC.
  • They are instead one of the diagnostic criteria for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypomelanotic Macules:

 

  • Hypomelanotic macules, often referred to as "Ash Leaf Spots," are a common skin finding in Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC) and are usually present from birth.

 

 

Option B. Shagreen Patch:

 

  • A Shagreen patch is a connective tissue nevus typically found on the lower back and is another characteristic cutaneous manifestation of TSC.

 

 

Option C. Koenen's Tumors:

 

  • Koenen's Tumors, or periungual fibromas, are benign fibrous growths that typically appear around the nails and are commonly associated with TSC.

Educational Objective:

 

  • While Hypomelanotic Macules, Shagreen patches, and Koenen's Tumors are characteristic of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, Axillary Freckles are not associated with TSC and are instead a feature of Neurofibromatosis Type 1.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 80.3

questions.text: Shagreen Patch is usually found in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lumbosacral Region

 

Option D.

 

  • Shagreen patches, which are Connective Tissue Nevi, are commonly located in the lumbosacral area and are considered one of the major features in the diagnostic criteria for TSC.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Face:

 

  • Shagreen patches are not typically found on the face. Facial Angiofibromas, also known as Adenoma Sebaceum, are the more common Facial Lesions associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC).

 

Option B. Cervical Region:

 

  • Shagreen patches are classically located in the lumbosacral region rather than the cervical region.

 

Option C. Limbs:

 

  • Shagreen patches are usually not found on the limbs. Hypomelanotic macules or ash leaf spots can be found on the limbs and are associated with TSC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shagreen Patches are typically located in the Lumbosacral Region and are a major diagnostic feature of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 80.11

questions.text: Which of the following findings is a Pathognomonic Sign of Neurofibromatosis 1?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Axillary Freckling

 

Option B.

 

  • Axillary freckling, also known as Crowe's sign, is highly suggestive of NF1 when found alongside other clinical criteria. It is considered one of the diagnostic features of NF1 due to its specificity to the condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Café-au-lait Macules:

 

  • Café-au-lait macules are not pathognomonic for Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) as they can be seen in several other conditions, including McCune-Albright syndrome and Legius syndrome.

 

Option C. Shagreen Patch:

 

  • Shagreen patches are associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC), not NF1.

 

Option D. Bilateral Acoustic Neuromas:

 

  • Bilateral Acoustic Neuromas are pathognomonic for Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2), not NF1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Axillary Freckling (Crowe's Sign) is a pathognomonic sign of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), which is one of the diagnostic criteria for this genetic disorder.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 80.2

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulsed Dye Laser

 

Option A.

 

  • Pulsed dye laser (PDL) therapy is considered the treatment of choice for port wine stains (PWS), which is the condition shown in the image.
  • PDL works by targeting the vascular endothelium, causing selective photo thermolysis of blood vessels, which helps in lightening the lesion without significant damage to surrounding tissue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Nd YAG laser:

 

  • Nd YAG laser penetrates deeper into tissue and is typically used for vascular lesions that are resistant to PDL or for deeper vessels.
  • However, it carries a higher risk of scarring and pigment changes compared to PDL.

 

Option C. CO2 Laser:

 

  • CO2 laser is primarily used for skin resurfacing and cutting, not for treating vascular lesions like port wine stains.
  • It has a high risk of scarring and pigmentary changes when used for vascular lesions.

 

Option D. Q-switched Ruby Laser:

 

  • This type of laser is mainly used for pigmented lesions and tattoo removal, not typically for vascular lesions like port wine stains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pulsed dye laser is the treatment of choice for port wine stains due to its effectiveness and lower risk of adverse effects compared to other laser options.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 23.8
